review_title: Company messaging does not reflect experience as an employee
pros: Great place to network, build your career, work with well-known clients, brush up on trainings you're interested in, connect and interact with wonderful individuals, market-competitive wages (depending on your career level and if you're LLP or contractor), opportunity to move around and switch account work if desired.
cons: Depending on the account, management and leadership of the role you take, this can be a great experience or a terrible experience. My first role was horrendous leaving myself and others on the team incredibly stressed daily which impacted both mental and physical health. Anxiety attacks happening regularly by a team is a serious red flag that should be raised and addressed by leadership. It was explained to me that lack of budget meant lack of leadership, aid, resources, and assistance. Additionally, there is a tier system in the company, one of which you are either a full time employee at Accenture or a contractor provided with less benefits and hourly wages which I would make a case of being extremely under market value (how does the largest consulting company in the world justify paying full time staff based in the US less than $50K a year to provide support to a globally-known and profiting client?) If you decide to leave your role for another within Accenture, your notice and last day on current role is dependent on what your manager and future manager decides, meaning the traditional two weeks notice and you defining your start and end dates is out of your hands and decided by others. It can be two weeks or it can be extended for weeks on end without knowing a finalized end date...management makes that decision. This is not always the case, but a deep concern anyone should have when applying and wanting to leave their current role for another within Accenture. Cost of inflation has dramatically increased both in the US and globally in the past six months. Review process takes a year and decisions of pay increase, promotion, or bonuses are made by likely someone from leadership whom you don't interact with. You are pitched to leadership by a sponsor on if you should be promoted, they have 3 minutes to make your case. My understanding is that most employees within the Marketing Operations umbrella did not receive pay increases or promotions and focus was made on providing bonuses instead. As stated, the cost of living has increased significantly, November is when employees find out if they get promotions or increases in pay, and this week I have discovered that the company does not provide increases to accommodate COLA.

review_title: Accenture South Africa - I love you I love you not (Benefits verses Mental Health)
pros: Benefits such as 13th check, performance bonus, shares at reduced cost. Amazing subsidized medical aid (Camaf is the best). Excellent learning curriculum available. Generous learning and development stipend. Good opportunity to progress up the career ladder.
cons:
All the benefits can’t outweigh the toxic culture in Accenture South Africa. The leadership is archaic. White. Male. Decision making is dominated by those males and unfortunately those who have tried to challenge the status quo have come out short. 
Accenture global have superb programmes promoting mental health and role model leadership. Unfortunately South Africa has too many bad apples that are rotting the bunch. 
People are over worked and under valued.
Psychological safety is non-existent.

review_title: 'Lord of the Flies' meets Ponzi Scheme
pros:
Some projects have great visibility and give you the opportunity to travel internationally at a young age. If you get tapped internally you can spend time on cool projects and learn a lot.

There are very cool sides of Accenture that are worth joining -- Accenture Digital, Fjord, Accenture Interactive.
cons:
Long time's spent on the "bench", waiting to get called on projects. You would wait 3/4 months waiting for a project, but interviewing for new projects. Management gives no clear guidelines for skills you should be picking up to make it easier to get slotted for projects. In my starting vlass, most analysts were given projects where they mostly sat all day and did nothing.

Projects and Roles are found via interview process. You need to interview internally at shipper for roles, creating a lord of the flies type situation. Where everyone is competing, and networking all the time to get the best roles. But when you find a good role and are accepted for the role, you would often times be pulled from the project last minute because an MD had a 'pet-analyst' they were looking out for and would staff them instead.

The guidance was very unclear and unstructured. Projects are sold to internal employees as HL strategy projects, but are mostly copy-paste implementation solutions for SAP, Oracle, Salesforce, etc. Moreover, it's downright impossible to get off of projects, you could be stuck for 6-12 months in a clerical role.

If you're looking to build skills in consulting, it's only "good" by name itself, but overall think I would have preferred to go to a startup, or different firm.

review_title: Great projects, highly technical coworkers, too much big company bureaucracy
job_title: Technology Strategy Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very intelligent coworkers on strategy projects. Definitely more operationally focused. Most project scopes are internal efficiency "strategy" or new product development that drive efficiencies. Been a lot of fun work though; significantly better than my time at a Big 4 consulting firm. Most people have a technical or STEM background so it's nice that most decisions are data-driven.
cons: Too much bureaucracy to get things that make sense approved. The typical type of place where you have to be seen doing the right work by the right people for any of your hard / good work to get actually recognized. Not the type of place to applaud you for working well humbly. The people who send the most emails and set up the most meetings get the most plaudits, not the ones actually focusing on successful client-value delivery.

pros:
Great company to work for, a lot of opportunity for growth and development. They offer junior employees a lot of support and managers (from my experience) are actively open to given more scope and responsibility to managees. All levels get great exposure to senior client stakeholders which is a plus

Provide a lot of training opportunities both on the job and via formal online training programs.

Work with good name brands and clients.
cons:
Experience very much depends on the practice you are in and the projects you work on. Experience and satisfaction can vary tremendously.

Very structured organisation with a lot of bureaucracy. To much for me in a lot of instances and this can hinder growth i.e, promotions are dependent on available funds which is allocated down by group, so even if your due and deserving doesn't mean you get it. Additionally, this creates a back log so time at level becomes important hindering fast development for good performers. Managers are often unable to change the status quo and help with issues like the one stated above so often you hear, "it's just the nature of a big organisation and everyone has to deal with it"

The sale of 'international opportunities' is in many instances a farce and can be very difficult to facilitate.

review_title: Find the right people and projects
job_title: Strategy Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
Great people depending on where you end up, lots of people will be open to mentoring. Great big-city offices and office culture. During Covid there has been little to no pressure to come in to the office but coming in voluntarily has been great and it has been easy to make friends.
Projects CAN be very interesting but you have to choose your path wisely, make sure it aligns to what you are interested in.
cons:
Work-life balance can vary significantly by project
Navigating internal politics within practices is never fun
Pay is below-par, particularly from Analyst level to Consultant
As an entry-level person, it can be tough to find where you would sit best in such a mammoth organization.

job_title: Executive Support Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful brand new office, wonderful team of EAs that are always ready and willing to help if needed, flexible work in office days (2 days a week and you choose the days each week), Stock sharing is available to you.
cons: They'll load you with too many people to support so it's often really hard to keep up with good support for everyone. The salaries are low for the cost of living in NYC. There was no compensation for the incredibly high inflation at this time. If you get a raise, it's miniscule. New EA management's style is not appreciated. Medical insurance is great until you start receiving your medical bills and see how much you have to pay out of pocket on top of the monthly premiums, but I assume it's that way with most corporations these days.

review_title: Not so great for experienced hires, lots of room for improvements
pros: Interesting customers and projects. Good access to relevant research and trainings.
cons: Very fixed mindset. Overfocus on using internal frameworks. For an experienced hire (like myself) it can be challenging to adapt to a very fixed way of working and solving problems. In other industries/in-house jobs you are in general given more freedom to attack and resolve issues based on your own experience. In Accenture parts of this freedom is taken away from you despite the fact that you have a long and relevant experience behind you. In addition, I would have expected more of a saying in picking out assignments instead of being reallocated into something without having a saying first.

review_title: (AFS only) Great place to work if you don't know what you want to do yet

-Very diverse on the federal side

cons:
-A lot depends on your project & manager
-Can be tedious work, even on large projects
-Once you know what you want to do, if it's not consulting OR MBA, plan an exit strategy
-If you're not used to straight up telling your supervisor exactly what your goals are, can get lost
-Can be hard to leave unless going to another consulting firm or grad school

job_title: News Publisher Review Associate in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- Very quick onboarding/access
- Job is very easy
- Suitable for young individuals with no work experience
cons:
- HR will not pay you for any days (and relocation) you have worked before leaving which is devastating if you're relocating for this job.
- Not suitable for parents with young children.
- Not suitable for experienced individuals. You'll be monitored every second, despite working remotely, as they have dozens of codes/status. 
- Extremely thorough micro management
- Process managers overcomplicate a very simple task.


This is all to justify their level of "quality" to their clients. Supervisors and team managers are also put under same amount of pressure. In the end it's all about the SLA and showing the client they're walking the extra astronomical unit barefooted. 

Keep in mind that this is an entry level position. They ideally want someone young to vet/discipline.

job_title: Business Development Representative (BDR) in San Jose, San Jose
pros: For now, it is WFH, that's a big plus. The pay is in USD for Costa Rica. Another plus. Low-level managers (Supervisors) are generally nice people.
cons: There are absolutely no skip-level meetings, not even once a year. My manager's manager is a micromanager who is completely disconnected from reality. The only thing she cares about is the numbers. I understand the numbers are very important, but instead of being a manager and trying to see the blockers and help the team, she only pushes her underlings (our supervisors) to increase the number of calls (sweatshop). In my two years working there, nobody ever came to ask us how we are doing and what we need if any. The salaries are not equal between the same positions and because of that, you sign a page that you will never speak about your salary with others. Our second-level manager is in the US and has no idea how things in Costa Rica are, except pushing for more calls every day. Very unhealthy way of managing a group of human beings. She pushes for reaching some goals so our fortune 10 company that we work for can double the bonus, but never says, that if you reach the goal you will receive something as intensive. I sent three emails to three different managers higher than my manager's position in a matter of 2 years. None of them ever answered my email. The emails were just asking for help with one thing or another, no complaints was included in those emails.

review_title: Job of my dreams at a great company!
pros:
-Company is growing so there are apportunities that might not immediately endist -Company provides regular communication, listen to and consider new ideas and continually encouraging growth, both personally and professionally -Company understands work-life balance and actually respects that

-Culture is conducive to creating friends and mentors with lots of opportunities to get involved based on your interests

-You get to work with top thought leaders in several Industries-smart, collaborative. willing to share you typically don't get such easy access and support)

-Our clients are top name brands and we are doing incredible things that impact the way business is done across the world. That's powerful! (and fun to be associated with)

-This is a place you can call homer many employees have been here a long time which

allows deep integration into the business and the ability to create pathways to success

for others
cons: No company is perfect. While we grow, there are things that are evolving (updating technology, adding office space, formalizing procedures, etc.) that come along with any growing company. It's important to not get hung up on what's wrong, but to focus on what is happening that is right and the progress in actions (not just words) that support that. With this growth is an opportunity to define the future and the role you play in it. That mindset is rewarded at Perficient.
